Unfortunately for XXXXXX like Behe, it is now widely know that:
 
 -The basal portion of the bacterial flagellum is homologous with Type III Protein Secretion Systems. Although the TTSS is probably decended from the flagellum (its used as a weapon against eukaryotic cells, which flagella probably predate), its a prime example of how components of "irreducibly complex" systems can have selectable functions outside of the IC system itself.
 
 -The flagellar motor proteins (MotA and MotB) are distant homologs of other bacterial membrane proteins (ExbB-ExbD).
 
 -The ATPase for flagellar construction has similar homologies, perhaps, as Rizzotti (2000) claims, suggesting evolution from a F1F0 ATPase.
 
 Conclusion: Behe's argument is fundamentally unsound. 
 
 -GFA

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Homologs in the Bacterial Flagellum
